citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The facility is not performing adequate daily observations on animals to accurately assess their health and well-being
and/or is not communicating in a timely manner to the Attending Veterinarian (AV) all of their findings.
The following animals had conditions that had not been communicated to the AV:
• A muntjac with three-day old wounds on its side after being attacked by another muntjac in the enclosure. The
muntjac also has a swelling under its right eye. The facility isolated the muntjac but has not contacted the AV to see if
treatment is needed.
• A lioness with a wound on the back of her neck for approximately two weeks. The facility has been treating this
wound by isolating the lioness and applying a topical spray. While the injury has improved, the AV has not been
contacted.
• Four ostriches with picking or barbering or fragile feathers. The facility did let the AV know that they were going to
supplement the ostriches with vitamin D, because the licensee was concerned about a vitamin D deficiency. No change
was seen with the supplementation. The licensee recently switched to alfalfa feed, because someone with a nutrition
background told him that this might be a vitamin K deficiency. The AV was not notified about continued feather issues nor
the switch to alfalfa. No bloodwork or other diagnostic tests have been done on the ostrich.
• A warthog with a broken right tusk
• An elk with long hooves. All claws are overgrown and the right rear inside claw is curving to the right. The facility
has been hesitant to immobilize the animal for trimming because she may be pregnant. However, they have not
discussed this with their AV.
• A domestic sheep with a cut wound on its right left leg. The AV had originally seen the sheep when the wound
occurred several months ago. However, the wound has not fully healed.
In addition the facility did not observe the following conditions during their daily observations and had not communicated
the issues to their AV: a young domestic goat with patchy hair loss on both sides of its body and a coyote with a
discolored bottom incisor tooth.
Failure to seek proper diagnosis and treatment for medical conditions may result in pain to the animal, worsening of the
conditions, spread of disease to additional animals if the conditions are contagious, or death.
Correct by ensuring daily observations are performed on all animals to assess their health and well-being, and that a
mechanism of direct and frequent communication exists so that timely and accurate information on problems of animal
health, behavior, and well-being is conveyed to the AV. The facility must communicate with the AV about the condition of
these animals and the AV must evaluate these animals and determine appropriate plans for diagnosis and treatment.
To be corrected by close of business on June 12, 2025.
A complete routine inspection was conducted on June 11, 2025. This inspection report is limited to the Direct non-
compliances identified during that inspection. An additional inspection report will be delivered with the other issues
identified during this inspection.
This inspection was conducted with facility representatives. The first exit briefing was conducted on June 11, 2025 with
facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The facility is not performing adequate daily observations on animals to accurately assess their health and well-being 
and/or is not communicating in a timely manner to the Attending Veterinarian (AV) all of their findings.  
 
The following animals had conditions that had not been communicated to the AV: 
•  A muntjac with three-day old wounds on its side after being attacked by another muntjac in the enclosure. The 
muntjac also has a swelling under its right eye. The facility isolated the muntjac but has not contacted the AV to see if 
treatment is needed.  
•  A lioness with a wound on the back of her neck for approximately two weeks. The facility has been treating this 
wound by isolating the lioness and applying a topical spray. While the injury has improved, the AV has not been 
contacted.  
•  Four ostriches with picking or barbering or fragile feathers. The facility did let the AV know that they were going to 
supplement the ostriches with vitamin D, because the licensee was concerned about a vitamin D deficiency. No change 
was seen with the supplementation. The licensee recently switched to alfalfa feed, because someone with a nutrition 
background told him that this might be a vitamin K deficiency. The AV was not notified about continued feather issues nor 
the switch to alfalfa. No bloodwork or other diagnostic tests have been done on the ostrich.  
•  A warthog with a broken right tusk  
•  An elk with long hooves. All claws are overgrown and the right rear inside claw is curving to the right. The facility 
has been hesitant to immobilize the animal for trimming because she may be pregnant. However, they have not 
discussed this with their AV.  
•  A domestic sheep with a cut wound on its right left leg. The AV had originally seen the sheep when the wound 
occurred several months ago. However, the wound has not fully healed.  
 
In addition the facility did not observe the following conditions during their daily observations and had not communicated 
the issues to their AV: a young domestic goat with patchy hair loss on both sides of its body and a coyote with a 
discolored bottom incisor tooth. 
 
Failure to seek proper diagnosis and treatment for medical conditions may result in pain to the animal, worsening of the 
conditions, spread of disease to additional animals if the conditions are contagious, or death.

Correct by ensuring daily observations are performed on all animals to assess their health and well-being, and that a 
mechanism of direct and frequent communication exists so that timely and accurate information on problems of animal 
health, behavior, and well-being is conveyed to the AV. The facility must communicate with the AV about the condition of 
these animals and the AV must evaluate these animals and determine appropriate plans for diagnosis and treatment. 
 
To be corrected by close of business on June 12, 2025. 
 
A complete routine inspection was conducted on June 11, 2025. This inspection report is limited to the Direct non-
compliances identified during that inspection. An additional inspection report will be delivered with the other issues 
identified during this inspection. 
 
This inspection was conducted with facility representatives. The first exit briefing was conducted on June 11, 2025 with 
facility representatives.
